data.title: Add programmatically selected snippet
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
See [this Stack Overflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45082780/how-do-i-add-a-snippet-programmatically) for more details.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Win 10 Pro (64 bit)

I am able to invoke `editor.action.insertSnippet` programmatically; however, I would like to _not_ require the user to select a snippet. Instead, I want to add a button that will invoke a predefined snippet on behalf of the user. Something along the lines of `editor.action.insertSelectedSnippet`.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Format Code For C++

Is there any support such that when I "format" my C++ code, the opening curly brace stays on the same line as the definition instead of being placed on a new line?

data.title: Test: new workspace format
data.body:
Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows @dbaeumer 
- [x] macOS @sandy081 
- [x] Linux @mjbvz 

We simplified and changed the format of the `*.code-workspace` files:
* the `id` property is no longer present. instead, the absolute path of the workspace file is now being used as identifier (so it will change if you move or rename the file)
* the `folders` entries are now real objects to support additional metadata later
* the `folder path` property is now just file paths (previously `URIs`) that can also be relative

To support relative paths in workspace files, a couple of changes went in:
* a relative path is always resolved against the folder (or root if stored in root) where the workspace file is saved to
* when saving a workspace or adding/removing folders, we always save paths as relative paths if possible. a path will be saved as relative when the parent folder of the workspace file is a parent of the root (in other words, we always put the relative path in unless it would result in "`../`" segments)

A couple of things to verify:
* check the contents of a workspace file make sense to you and is easy to understand
* make copies of a workspace and verify each can be opened into individual windows
* verify that adding/removing folders from within VSCode works properly and updates the path to be relative or absolute depending on the rule described above (no "`../`" ever)
* verify that saving a workspace to another location converts paths to either relative or absolute depending on the rule described above
* verify paths work cross OS (e.g. each OS can deal with backslash or slash as path segment)
* Windows: verify with special paths
  * UNC paths (`\\localhost\c$\my_dir`)
  * other drive letters (e.g. `D:`)

data.title: Test: Smoother transition into multi root workspaces
data.body:
Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows @seanmcbreen 
- [x] macOS @alexandrudima 
- [x] Linux @chrmarti 

The transition from a non-multi-root workspace into a workspace is now taking care of some state migration to make it less of a pain to transition into workspaces. We still require a window reload (for now) but otherwise the experience should be smooth.

To do the transition you should verify via:
* Adding folders to an empty workspace (via the File menu)
* Adding folders to a single-folder workspace (e.g. via the File menu)
* Saving a single-folder workspace (via File > Save Workspace As)

Verify:
* all UI state is migrated to the new workspace (e.g. opened editors)
* if you have dirty files you are not being prompted to save them and they restore properly in the workspace
* if you configured workspace settings (for the single-folder case), all settings that target the window are being migrated to the workspace file (e.g. statusbar visibility). Resource settings are not migrated because they will continue to work from the folder.

data.title: Test: Windows terminal session renaming via native module
data.body:
#31818

- [x] Windows @bpasero
- [x] Windows @roblourens

Complexity 4

*This is mostly a copy of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31776 from last iteration as the mechanism for doing it completely changed*

**Use [ProcessExplorer](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/process-explorer) to track process trees.**

- Verify that the title changes as the process changes and that the title makes sense. eg: `cmd -> cmd, powershell -> powershell, npm -> node, git log -> git, etc`.
- Verify that the title only changes to the first child process (if one exists) of the shell unless the child is one of `[bash, cmd, powershell]` where we'd check that child's children etc. eg: `Initial shell = cmd`. Git log will spawn a child process called less `cmd -> git -> less`. The title will show git and not less since git is the first child of cmd. If the tree is  `cmd -> powershell -> bash -> cmd -> powershell` then the title would be powershell since all those processes are shells.
- Verify that the terminal title is not overridden after the user or an API sets it.
- It is known that creating an external process (eg: `start notepad`) will have the title stuck as notepad until that process is closed.

data.title: Test: More ways to get into multi root workspace
data.body:
Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows @chrisdias 
- [x] macOS @aeschli 
- [x] Linux @Tyriar 

We make it easier to enter a multi root workspace from various uses where multiple folders are specified.

**Via Command Line:**
* Verify the new command line flag `--add` can be used to add folders to an active window (requires a window to be opened)
  * Verify for an empty workspace, a single folder workspace and a multi root workspace
* Verify that multiple folders specified from the command line open into a single window as multi root workspace

**Via Native UX**
* Verify that multiple folders picked from File > Open open into a single window as multi root workspace
* macOS: verify that dropping multiple folders on the dock icon open into a single window as multi root workspace 

**Via Drag & Drop**
* Verify that dropping 1-N folders into the files explorer allows to add the folders to the workspace
  * for a single folder workspace this will prompt
  * currently not supported on an empty workspace yet
* Verify that dropping 1 folder into the editor area opens a window with that folder
* Verify that dropping 2-N folders into the editor area opens a window with all folders as workspace

data.title: Test: Terminal xterm.js v3
data.body:
Refs: #32809

**OS**
- [x] Windows @dbaeumer 
- [x] OS X @sandy081 
- [x] Linux @alexandrudima 

Complexity: 3

The terminal got a large refactor and is now 100% TypeScript under the covers. Please do a general test of the terminal with a a particular focus on running programs inside the alt buffer (eg. vim, tmux). A big change that came in is that now the alt buffer *never* has scrollback or a scrollbar as defined by the spec.

data.title: Support for drag and drop from search and problems
data.body:
The explorer allows to drag a file to the editor area to open the file there. We should expand this to other locations:
* search results (only the file name)
* problems (only on files in the list)

data.title: Preserve format of paths in workspace file when writing
data.body:
There is a couple of cases where today we change the paths in a way that might not be desired:
* we convert path separators to the OS path
* we convert relative/absolute paths automatically

We should try to preserve as much of the workspace file format as possible. For example, when a folder is added or removed, we should try to only write the change to the folder in question and not all.

data.title: Test: Multiple SCM repository support
data.body:
Complexity: 4

- [x] tester1 - @egamma
- [x] tester2 - @isidorn 
- [x] tester3 - @mjbvz 

This milestone we started supporting multiple SCM repositories.

- Make sure the legacy story of having a single repository works as before. Please test the git extension as well as one of the current SCM providers out there (Hg, TFS, Perforce).
- If you open a workspace with multiple folders, each of them being a git repository, they should all appear in the SCM viewlet as separate repositories. Make sure actions, gestures, global commands work as expected. Give it a proper smoke test.
- If you remove a folder from a workspace, its respective repository should also be removed iff there are no open files from that same folder.
- If you open a no-workspace, no-folder window, no repositories should appear (#33288). If you open a single file from a git repository, it should appear in the SCM viewlet.
- Make sure git repositories can coexist with other SCM provider repositories in the same window.

data.title: Duplication/Layering in simpleFindWidget

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
I've noticed some very fishy code when I looked inside the `/editor/find` folder thanks to #32113

* the `/editor/` folder should not take a dependency on the workbench. We don't have a linter warning / pre-commit hook for it, but using the CSS class name `.monaco-workbench` in the `/editor/` folder indicates that something is wrong or badly layered.

* some similar-looking CSS appears in `simpleFindWidget.css` and in `findWidget.css`. A decision should be done if these are two separate widgets or a single widget used in different ways. If these are two different widgets, then the workbench specific widget should move to the `/workbench/` folder, together with its CSS and images and all. If you'd want to reuse some code, then that's also fine, but then there should be no exact CSS rules that end up e.g. inlining the same image in multiple places in `workbench.main.css`. As it appears right now, we are somewhere in the middle.

data.title: Test: ESLint multi folder support
data.body:
Complexity: 4

OS:

- [x]  any OS @ramya-rao-a 
- [x] any OS (Linux) @Tyriar 

## Setup

Install the attached vsix using the code command line tools. Please note that you have to rename the zip to vsix before installing

[vscode-eslint-1.3.0.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1257914/vscode-eslint-1.3.0.zip)

## Test

Basically make sure that the ESLint extension behaves correctly in a single file, single folder and multi folder setup. All ESLint settings described here https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dbaeumer.vscode-eslint should work as a resource setting. The only window setting is: `"eslint.trace.server"` to enabling tracing between the language client and the language server.

The commands for ESLint to enable, disable and to create a .eslintrc file should show a picker in a multi workspace folder setup to pick the folder to enable or disable ESLint in. In a file setup a warning message should be shown in a one folder setup no picker should appear.

data.title: Introduce a mechanism that can be used to activate debug extensions just in time
data.body:
With the new debug API we need to register `DebugConfigurationProvider` early enough so that VS Code has them available when it needs them.

Since `DebugConfigurationProvider` are typically registered in the `activate` function of an extension, we have to find a way to activate the corresponding extensions before debugging starts.

I've tried to use these actions to activate the extension that registers a `DebugConfigurationProvider`:
```json
    "onCommand:workbench.action.debug.selectandstart",
    "onCommand:workbench.action.debug.configure",
    "onCommand:workbench.action.debug.start",
```
but most of the time the registration in the extension does not happen in time for VS Code  to pick it up. So I had to resort to `"*"` with the side effect that the extension now starts on startup of VS Code.

So we need a more robust mechanism that allows to activate extensions for registering `DebugConfigurationProvider` just in time before debugging starts.

@jrieken can provide the details.

---|---|---

terraform|mau|0.0.16
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1

Steps to Reproduce:

2. Start code `code .`
